choices.text: Bacterial meningitis
Tubercular meningitis
Fungal meningitis.
Aseptic meningitis.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl named Malika is brought to the clinic by her mother with symptoms of acute fever and vomiting. The mother reports that the child has been avoiding loud sounds and bright lights from a recent family wedding by staying in her room for the past two days. During the examination, the child exhibits a sign that raises the suspicion of meningitis. A cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample is collected and analyzed, yielding the following results: lymphocyte count of 150 cells/mm^3, CSF protein level of 110 mg%, and CSF glucose level of 75 mg%. Based on the clinical features and CSF findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aseptic meningitis.

 

Option D:

 

Aseptic/ Viral meningitis is suggested by the presence of lymphocytic pleocytosis (elevated lymphocyte count in the CSF), an elevated protein level, and a normal glucose level in the CSF. These findings are consistent with viral meningitis, which is a common cause of aseptic meningitis. The child's avoidance of bright lights (photophobia) and loud sounds (phonophobia) along with the presence of fever and vomiting support this diagnosis.

 

Characteristic 

 

  • Kernig’s sign positive
  • CSF - raised lymphocytes, raised protein and normal glucose

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis:

Bacterial meningitis is often associated with a rapid onset of symptoms, including fever, vomiting, and signs of meningeal irritation such as neck stiffness.

  • The CSF findings in bacterial meningitis typically show an elevated white blood cell count (predominantly neutrophils), elevated protein, and decreased glucose levels. In this case, the CSF profile (lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and normal glucose) is not consistent with bacterial meningitis.

 

Option B. Tubercular meningitis:

  • Tubercular meningitis is a form of meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • The CSF findings in tubercular meningitis may show lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and decreased glucose. However, the clinical presentation and CSF findings in this case do not strongly suggest tubercular meningitis.

 

Option C. Fungal meningitis:

 

  • Fungal meningitis is rare and is usually seen in individuals with compromised immune systems.
  • The CSF findings in fungal meningitis may include lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and normal to mildly decreased glucose. However, the clinical presentation and CSF findings in this case are not highly suggestive of fungal meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aseptic meningitis refers to non-bacterial, non-tubercular, and non-fungal causes of meningitis. Viral infections are the most common cause of aseptic meningitis.
  • The CSF findings in aseptic meningitis often include lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and normal glucose.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Page No 6852

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy named Mohan is brought to the healthcare facility with symptoms of acute fever and projectile vomiting. His mother reports that he is experiencing photophobia. Upon physical examination, the child shows neck rigidity and a positive Brudzinski sign, leading to a clinical suspicion of meningitis. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals a predominance of neutrophils, a protein level of 72 mg%, and a glucose level of 30 mg%. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the combination of clinical features and CSF findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial meningitis

 

Option A:

 

 

Based on the clinical history given and the Brudzinski sign positivity, it’s a clearcut case of meningitis.

 

  • Bacterial meningitis is characterized by the acute onset of symptoms, including fever, headache, vomiting, photophobia, and signs of meningeal irritation (neck rigidity, positive Brudzinski sign).
  • The CSF findings in bacterial meningitis typically show an elevated white blood cell count (predominantly neutrophils), elevated protein, and decreased glucose levels. In this case, the CSF profile (neutrophilic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and decreased glucose) is consistent with bacterial meningitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tubercular meningitis:

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is a form of meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • The CSF findings in tubercular meningitis may show lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and decreased glucose. However, the clinical presentation and CSF findings in this case, particularly the predominance of neutrophils, do not align with tubercular meningitis.

 

Option C. Fungal meningitis:

 

  • Fungal meningitis is rare and is usually seen in individuals with compromised immune systems.
  • The CSF findings in fungal meningitis may include lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and normal to mildly decreased glucose. The presence of neutrophils in the CSF is not typical for fungal meningitis.

 

Option D. Aseptic meningitis:

 

  • Aseptic meningitis refers to non-bacterial causes of meningitis, commonly viral infections.
  • The CSF findings in aseptic meningitis typically reveal an elevated white blood cell count, predominantly lymphocytes, elevated protein, and normal glucose. The presence of neutrophils in the CSF is not characteristic of aseptic meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In bacterial meningitis, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis commonly reveals increased white blood cell count, mainly neutrophils, elevated protein levels, and reduced glucose levels.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-562-563

choices.text: Bacterial meningitis and antibiotics.
Tubercular meningitis and Supportive care
Bacterial meningitis and Supportive care
Tubercular meningitis and ATT.

questions.text: A father brings his 10 years old daughter with features of headache, fever and anorexia for last 24 days. As her mother is ill because of a chronic AFB +ve disease, there is no one to care of her. Recently, her father returned home and brought both of them to the hospital. On examination, she had photophobia and neck rigidity. A CECT was done which revealed the enhancement of meninges because of the protein accumulation. A provisional diagnosis of meningitis was made. Which type meningitis can be associated with these clinical findings and what will be its treatment modality?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tubercular meningitis and ATT

 

Option D:

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is treated with antitubercular therapy (ATT), which includes multiple drugs like isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol.
  • ATT is administered for an extended duration to effectively treat and prevent the recurrence of tubercular meningitis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Bacterial meningitis and antibiotics:

  • Bacterial meningitis, often caused by organisms like Streptococcus pneumoniae or Neisseria meningitidis, presents with acute symptoms, including headache, fever, photophobia, and signs of meningeal irritation (neck rigidity).
  • The contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) showing meningeal enhancement suggests inflammation of the meninges.
  • While bacterial meningitis is a consideration, the prolonged duration (24 days) and the history of a chronic AFB-positive disease in the mother make tubercular meningitis more likely.

 

Option B. Tubercular meningitis and supportive care:

  • Tubercular meningitis is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and can have a subacute or chronic presentation.
  • The history of a chronic AFB-positive disease in the mother raises suspicion for tuberculosis. Tubercular meningitis may present with prolonged symptoms, including headache, fever, photophobia, and signs of meningeal irritation.
  • Treatment for tubercular meningitis typically involves antitubercular therapy (ATT) in addition to supportive care.

 

Option C. Bacterial meningitis and supportive care:

 

  • Supportive care is crucial in the management of bacterial meningitis, but antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment.
  • Given the chronic nature of the symptoms and the history, tubercular meningitis is a more likely diagnosis in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is a chronic form of meningitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
  • Treatment for tubercular meningitis involves antitubercular therapy (ATT) for an extended duration, along with supportive care.

 

Summary Table Showing Important Csf Pathologies

 

 

NOTE - Normal clinical findings in CSF analysis (RULE OF 60)

 

  • CSF Glucose Levels = 2/3rd of Blood Sugar Levels (RBS) = 60-80 mg/dL
  • CSF Protein Levels = 60-80 mg/dL.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-562-563

choices.text: Female Anopheles mosquito.
Male Anopheles mosquito.
Culex mosquito.
Aedes Aegypti mosquito.

questions.text: An 8-year-old child is brought to the hospital with an acute onset of fever, headache, and vomiting, without accompanying nausea. Clinical examination reveals photophobia and neck rigidity, leading to a suspicion of meningitis. A CT scan identifies lesions on the bilateral thalami, and a lumbar puncture is performed. The CSF analysis shows 150 lymphocytes/mm^3, a protein level of 105 mg%, and a glucose level of 75 mg%. The causative organism is identified as the most common cause of encephalitis in India. What is the vector for this organism?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Culex mosquito

 

Option C:

 

Based on the given clinical history and the CT findings of bilateral thalami involvement, it’s most likely a case of Japanese Encephalitis.

 

  • It is the most common cause of encephalitis in India.
  • It is transmitted by Culex Mosquito (also spreads Filariasis, West Nile fever) 
  • CSF findings of raised lymphocytes, raised protein and normal CSF glucose.
  • It is also diagnosed by JE specific IgM ELISA in Serum and CSF.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Female Anopheles mosquito:

 

  • Anopheles mosquitoes are primarily known for transmitting the Plasmodium parasite, which causes malaria. They are not typically associated with viral encephalitis.
  • The clinical presentation and CSF findings described in the scenario are not consistent with malaria.

 

Option B. Male Anopheles mosquito:

 

  • Male mosquitoes, in general, do not transmit diseases, as they primarily feed on nectar and plant juices. Only female mosquitoes require a blood meal for egg development.
  • This option is not likely, as it refers to the non-disease-transmitting gender of Anopheles mosquitoes.

 

Option D. Aedes aegypti mosquito:

 

  • Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are primarily associated with transmitting viruses such as dengue, Zika, and chikungunya. They are not typically associated with Japanese encephalitis virus.
  • This option is less likely given the context of Japanese encephalitis being the most common cause of encephalitis in India.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Culex mosquitoes are known vectors for various viruses, including Japanese encephalitis virus, which is the most common cause of viral encephalitis in India.

The clinical presentation, along with the CSF findings, is suggestive of viral encephalitis. Culex mosquitoes are relevant vectors for this scenario.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Page number 7058

choices.text: Pseudotumor cerebri
Tubercular meningitis
Viral meningitis
Acute bacterial meningitis

questions.text: A 7-year-old child undergoes a lumbar puncture, and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample is shown in the image. Clinically, the child presents with mild fever, nuchal rigidity, and intermittent stupor. CSF analysis reveals 85 white blood cells per microliter, all of which are lymphocytes, a negative Gram stain, a protein level of 150 mg/dL, and a glucose level of 15 mg/dL. A CT scan with contrast demonstrates enhancement of the basal cisterns. Based on the clinical presentation and examination findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tubercular meningitis

 

Option B:

 

  • Based on the clinical history of mild fever and intermittent stupor along with neck rigidity, it’s classically a case of Tubercular meningitis.
  • The CT scan with contrast can be an excellent clue for diagnosing tubercular meningitis. Exudate in the basal cisterns that show enhancement by contrast material is typical.
  • The CSF findings include- Raised lymphocytes, raised protein and decreased CSF glucose.
  • The physical examination of CSF will show the Cob web coagulum.
  • The treatment is starting with ATT and Steroids.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pseudotumor cerebri:

 

  • Pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension) is characterized by increased intracranial pressure without an obvious cause. It can cause headaches and visual disturbances.
  • The CSF findings in pseudotumor cerebri typically show an increased opening pressure but do not exhibit the significant lymphocytic pleocytosis seen in the provided scenario.

 

Option C. Viral meningitis:

 

  • Viral meningitis is often characterized by a milder course than bacterial meningitis. It commonly presents with fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity.
  • The CSF findings in viral meningitis typically show lymphocytic pleocytosis, normal or slightly elevated protein, and normal glucose. The enhancement of basal cisterns is not a typical feature.

 

Option D. Acute bacterial meningitis:

 

  • Acute bacterial meningitis is a medical emergency with a rapid onset of symptoms, including fever, severe headache, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status.
  • The CSF findings in acute bacterial meningitis often show neutrophilic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and decreased glucose. The enhancement of basal cisterns is less commonly seen compared to tubercular meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tubercular meningitis is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and is characterized by a subacute or chronic course. It commonly presents with fever, nuchal rigidity, and altered mental status.
  • The CSF findings in tubercular meningitis often show lymphocytic pleocytosis, elevated protein, and decreased glucose. The enhancement of basal cisterns on contrast-enhanced CT is a characteristic feature.

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-562-563.

choices.text: Order MRI of the head.
Order lateral neck radiograph.
Perform a lumbar puncture.
Prescribe oral antibiotics.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy is presented to the clinic by his mother due to a 3-day history of fever and stiff neck. He also suffers from a sore throat, which has led to a 1-day history of odynophagia, causing him to avoid eating. During the examination, the patient is found to be alert and oriented, with nuchal rigidity and a noted posterior pharyngeal midline fullness. Additionally, he exhibits drooling which appears to be a mechanism to avoid the pain associated with swallowing. What is the next best step in the management of this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Order lateral neck radiograph.

 

Option B:

 

The patient's presentation with fever, stiff neck, sore throat, difficulty swallowing, and drooling is suggestive of a retropharyngeal abscess, which is a collection of pus in the tissue at the back of the throat. This can be a life-threatening condition if not diagnosed and treated promptly. A lateral neck radiograph is the appropriate next step to visualize the soft tissues of the neck and confirm the presence of an abscess, which may present as widening of the prevertebral space.

 

Explanation:

 

 Option A. Order MRI of the head:

 

  • Description: MRI of the head is a diagnostic imaging test used to visualize brain structures.
  • Significance: In this scenario, the symptoms and signs presented (fever, sore throat, nuchal rigidity) suggest a concern for a potential throat infection rather than an immediate need for an MRI of the head.

 

Option C. Perform a lumbar puncture:

 

  • Description: A lumbar puncture is a procedure to collect cerebrospinal fluid from the spinal canal using a needle.
  • Significance: While nuchal rigidity is a sign of potential meningitis, the patient's presentation with throat symptoms suggests a more immediate concern for an upper airway issue. Lumbar puncture is not the first-line investigation in this context.

 

Option D. Prescribe oral antibiotics:

 

  • Description: Prescribing oral antibiotics is a common treatment for bacterial infections.
  • Significance: Antibiotics are typically prescribed for bacterial infections, but in this case, the immediate concern is to assess the airway and rule out epiglottitis before initiating antibiotic therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A lateral neck radiograph is an essential diagnostic tool that can identify the presence of a retropharyngeal abscess, which typically requires urgent surgical consultation for possible drainage and intravenous antibiotic therapy.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition page number 8682

choices.text: Stage 1
Stage 2
Stage 3
Stage 4

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to your clinic with a recent diagnosis of tubercular meningitis. The child presents with neurological manifestations, including seizures, focal deficits, and meningeal signs. A cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination has confirmed the diagnosis. As part of the management plan, you decide it's essential to stage the child's tubercular meningitis to tailor the treatment approach effectively. Based on the child's clinical features, into which stage of tubercular meningitis would this child be classified?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stage 2.

 

Option B:

 

Stage 2 tubercular meningitis is characterized by the presence of neurological manifestations such as seizures, focal neurological deficits, and meningeal signs, without advanced alterations in consciousness. This stage indicates moderate disease, where the symptoms are more pronounced than in Stage 1, which involves general symptoms like fever and headache without focal neurological signs, but not as severe as in Stage 3, where there is significant alteration in consciousness, including stupor and coma.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Stage 1: This early stage of the disease presents with non-specific symptoms such as fever, headache, and lethargy, without overt neurological deficits or altered consciousness.

 

Option C. Stage 3: Represents advanced disease with significant neurological compromise, including severe alteration in consciousness (stupor or coma), more severe focal deficits, and possibly evidence of hydrocephalus or infarcts on imaging.

 

Option D. Stage 4: Incorrect option as it does not exist in the standard staging system for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Stages of TB Meningitis

 

 

Ref: OP Ghai 9th Edition, Page No-562-563.

choices.text: No further investigation is required
Repeat lumbar puncture in all cases
Refer to an ENT specialist for potential sensorineural deafness evaluation
Conduct a tuberculosis workup for every patient

questions.text: A 4-year-old child, who has been hospitalized for the past 14 days due to meningitis, has responded well to treatment and is scheduled for discharge today. As part of the discharge protocol for patients recovering from meningitis, which essential investigation or referral should be considered to address potential complications associated with the condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Refer to an ENT specialist for potential sensorineural deafness evaluation

 

Option C:

 

Sensorineural deafness is a recognized complication of meningitis, and assessing hearing is crucial before discharge to ensure any hearing impairment is identified and managed early.

 

An ENT referral for a hearing evaluation is recommended for children recovering from meningitis to facilitate timely intervention and support.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. No further investigation is required: Dismissing the need for any post-treatment evaluation overlooks the potential complications associated with meningitis, such as hearing loss.

 

Option B. Repeat lumbar puncture in all cases: While a repeat lumbar puncture might be necessary in specific cases to ensure the resolution of the infection, it is not a blanket requirement for all patients at discharge.

 

Option D. Conduct a tuberculosis workup for every patient: A tuberculosis workup is condition-specific and not a standard discharge procedure for all meningitis cases unless there is a clinical suspicion of tubercular meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sensorineural deafness is one of the complications seen after streptococcus pneumonia meningitis so we should get ENT reference

 

Ref: Nelson 20th Edition, Page No 2945.

choices.text: Fibrillary astrocytoma
Pilocytic astrocytoma
Glioblastoma multiforme
Anaplastic astrocytoma

questions.text: A worried father brings his 4-year-old child to the emergency department at 6 AM with uncontrollable crying throughout the night. Further history reveals headache, vomiting, lethargy, and irritability. Routine investigations are unremarkable, but MRI and CT scans show a cystic mass with enhancement in the cerebellar region, as depicted in the image. A guided biopsy reveals pathology consistent with a specific type of brain tumor. What is the reason behind the pathological findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Pilocytic astrocytoma

 

Option B:

 

The clinical presentation of headache, vomiting, lethargy, and irritability, along with the radiological findings of a cystic mass with enhancement in the cerebellar region, suggests a pediatric brain tumor.

 

 

Pilocytic astrocytoma is a common pediatric brain tumor that typically presents as a cystic mass with enhancing mural nodules, most commonly located in the cerebellum. The biopsy findings consistent with pilocytic astrocytoma correlate with the radiological and clinical presentation described.

 

Astrocytoma:

 

M/C brain tumor overall, M/C location is Cerebellum.

 

M/c type is JPA (JUVENILE PILOCYTIC ASTROCYTOMA)

 

Pilocytic astrocytoma: it is benign tumor (WHO Grade 1). M/c seen in the posterior fossa.

 

Clinical features:  Classic triad- headache, nausea, vomiting, lethargy, irritability, ataxia.

 

Diagnosis: Brain tumor suspected child should undergo emergency imaging with MRI with or without gadolinium.

 

Treatment: Surgical excision.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fibrillary astrocytoma: Fibrillary astrocytoma typically presents as a diffusely infiltrating tumor without well-defined cystic components, making it less likely in this scenario.

 

Option C. Glioblastoma multiforme: Glioblastoma multiforme is a highly malignant brain tumor that typically occurs in adults and is rare in children. It presents differently on imaging and pathology compared to pilocytic astrocytoma.

 

Option D. Anaplastic astrocytoma: Anaplastic astrocytoma is a high-grade astrocytic tumor with more aggressive features than pilocytic astrocytoma, often lacking the classic cystic appearance seen in pilocytic astrocytoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter-526, Page No-10480-10507

choices.text: Astrocytoma
Ependymoma
Meningioma
Medulloblastoma

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 6-year-old child to the pediatric department due to rapidly increasing head size and complaints of frequent headaches, double vision, and facial asymmetry. MRI reveals a hypointense mass compressing the brain stem. Pathological examination yields the image shown. What is the most probable diagnosis based on the history and pathological examination?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ependymoma

 

Option B:

 

The clinical presentation of rapidly increasing head size, headaches, double vision, and facial asymmetry, along with the MRI findings of a hypointense mass compressing the brain stem, suggests a pediatric brain tumor.

 

 

Image shows pseudorosettes

 

Ependymoma is a type of brain tumor that commonly occurs in children and is often located near the brain stem. The pathological examination image provided shows characteristic features of ependymoma, such as perivascular pseudorosettes and ependymal rosettes, confirming the diagnosis.

 

Treatment: surgical excision with craniospinal irradiation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Astrocytoma: Astrocytoma is another type of brain tumor, but it typically presents differently on imaging and pathology compared to ependymoma.

 

Option C. Meningioma: Meningiomas are usually slow-growing tumors arising from the meninges, and they are rare in children. The clinical presentation and pathological features described are not typical of meningioma.

 

Option D. Medulloblastoma: Medulloblastoma is a highly malignant brain tumor that commonly occurs in children and presents with symptoms similar to those described. However, the pathological features of medulloblastoma differ from those shown in the image provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ependymoma: MC seen in children, it is derived from ependymal lining of the 4th ventricle.

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Headaches
  • Double vision
  • Facial asymmetry
  • Hydrocephalus (due to involvement of 4th ventricle).

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter-526, Page No-10480-10507.

choices.text: Surgery+ Radiation therapy
Radiation
Chemotherapy
Surgery +chemotherapy

questions.text: A mother brings her 10-year-old son to the pediatric OPD with complaints of visual disturbance and decreased school performance. On evaluation, the child is found to have delayed sexual maturity and decreased growth. Hormone profile testing reveals decreased levels of thyroxine, growth hormone, and sex hormones. Imaging studies show calcification and a cystic structure in the brain, as depicted below. What is the preferred management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Surgery+ Radiation therapy

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation of visual disturbance, growth retardation, delayed sexual maturity, and hormone deficiencies, along with imaging findings of calcification and a cystic structure in the brain, strongly suggests craniopharyngioma.

 

Craniopharyngioma is a benign tumor derived from Rathke's pouch, often presenting with the following Clinical features:

 

  • Visual disturbance (due to compression of optic chiasma by tumor on)
  • Growth retardation, decreased sexual maturity due to hypopituitorism.

 

Diagnosis: MRI>CT

 

Treatment: surgery+ radiation.

 

Surgery is done to completely remove the tumor along with radiotherapy to reduce the local recurrence rate and improve long time survival.

 

Chemotherapy at present has no role in craniopharyngioma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Craniopharyngioma, a benign tumor commonly presenting with visual disturbances, growth retardation, and hormone deficiencies. The preferred management of craniopharyngioma involves surgical resection of the tumor followed by adjuvant radiation therapy. Surgery aims to achieve complete or near-complete tumor removal, alleviating mass effect on surrounding structures and improving symptoms. Adjuvant radiation therapy is commonly employed to reduce the risk of tumor recurrence.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter-524, Page No-10505
